channel.title: Shutting Down Computers on a Network (WinXp)
channel.description:
To shut down computers on any network, you just need access to the command prompt and an account with admin privileges, or the ablility to run programs as an admin.
1. Go to Start - Accessories - Command Prompt. Right-click and select Run As
2. Type in an admin username and password (skip this if your account is an admin account)
3. In the command prompt screen, type shutdown -i
4. This brings up a dialog that lets you shut down any computer on the network, as long as you know its name!

item.title: Shutting Down Computers on a Network (WinXp)
item.dc:creator: @kmb Kmb
item.description:
@kmb wrote:

h44ckzor pwnage:

Kmb, I made the same mistake as you and teached it to some jackass who used to be my friend and now he has told everyone and he takes credits for it.

Nah, I ain’t worried about the credit. It pisses me off when I have to keep spamming shutdown -a to the command prompt all the time…

Read full topic
item.source: Shutting Down Computers on a Network (WinXp)

item.title: Shutting Down Computers on a Network (WinXp)
item.dc:creator: @Bookworm9405 Bookworm9405
item.description:
@Bookworm9405 wrote:

Well, the thing is, I only found out because our school’s default student account (for students who don’t have an account or whose account is broken), is an admin account! So I found that whenever I need admin privileges, all I have to do is log into it. Not smart, not smart.

Read full topic
item.source: Shutting Down Computers on a Network (WinXp)

item.title: Shutting Down Computers on a Network (WinXp)
item.dc:creator: @kmb Kmb
item.description:
@kmb wrote:

This is the reason I press cntrl + s every two seconds whenever I type anything at school. Tbh, it actually is my fault, I taught this to an immature idiot some years ago =/

Read full topic

To shut down computers on any network, you just need access to the command prompt and an account with admin privileges, or the ablility to run programs as an admin.

  1. Go to Start - Accessories - Command Prompt. Right-click and select Run As

  2. Type in an admin username and password (skip this if your account is an admin account)
